channel.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
channel.description:
[b]About:[/b] Back in 2006 Newbiehacker released a simple 3D engine written in java (I don't have a copy of the original nengine ask him directly if interested) I have used it for multiple works including a Runescape model viewer that I had once released. I have dusted the source off the model viewer and converted it to Javascript using html5 canvas.
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/9GTb4.png[/img]
[b]github:[/b] https://github.com/silabsoft/pos3D
[b]Example:[/b] http://silabsoft.org/pos3d/
Currently its set to not fill faces because I removed the face color value for the time being.
Known Issues: [IMG]http://i.imgur.com/K08kG.png[/img] - Zsorting is not functioning.

item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

have you looked at the recent source it uses all the same objects now it really seems the way I am drawing the model is the issue, because even if I remove the transform and face sorting its still getting around 12 fps. If I lets say only draw 10 faces it gets around 34 fps

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:27, topic:448771”]That is completely what its missing your right, I think what ill do is hold a transform offset array (3x float per vector) rather than cloning the vertex object array

I am now reusing most of the objects but I did not see a significant performance boost, I am running a pretty shit laptop though lets see what other users get for FPS.

Post your average FPS: http://silabsoft.org/pos3d/[/quote]

I’m getting around ~14 FPS. If the faces were filled, however, you could do some culling and cut the rendering workload quite a bit, but there ought to be a way to improve the speed even with a wireframe.

edit: Are you using the centroid depth-sort again?

edit2: If you want the backface culling to work, consider changing the projection plane normal to not be the zero vector… also, you may also want to cache the model-space face normals, and consider not needing to create a new model when applying transformations. Whatever you can do to avoid creating temporary objects every tick will greatly help the garbage collector.

Read full topic

That is completely what its missing your right, I think what ill do is hold a transform offset array (3x float per vector) rather than cloning the vertex object array

I am now reusing most of the objects but I did not see a significant performance boost, I am running a pretty shit laptop though lets see what other users get for FPS.

Post your average FPS: http://silabsoft.org/pos3d/

item.source: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

The model is destroyed because you’re performing the conversion from model to view space on the vertices again after they’ve already been transformed once, so you need a way to store the transformed vertices distinct from the model’s untouched vertices without just allocating new ones every frame as that is slow.
As you probably know, RuneScape handles this issue by keeping an array of the view-space positions of the vertices in a separate pair of arrays, e.g.

  public void render_oblique_tile(int tile_x, int tile_y, ObliqueTile oblique, int yaw_sin, int yaw_cos, int pitch_sin, int pitch_cos) {
    int count = oblique.vertex_x.length;
    for (int l1 = 0; l1 < count; l1++) {
      int x = oblique.vertex_x[l1] - camera_x;
      int z = oblique.vertex_z[l1] - camera_z;
      int y = oblique.vertex_y[l1] - camera_y;
      int prime = y * yaw_sin + x * yaw_cos >> 16;
      y = y * yaw_cos - x * yaw_sin >> 16;
      x = prime;
      prime = z * pitch_sin - y * pitch_cos >> 16;
      y = z * pitch_cos + y * pitch_sin >> 16;
      z = prime;
      if (y < 50)
        return;
      if (oblique.face_texture != null) {
        ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[l1] = x;
        ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[l1] = z;
        ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[l1] = y;
      }
      ObliqueTile.vertex_view_x[l1] = Rasterizer.viewport_center_x + (x << 9) / y;
      ObliqueTile.vertex_view_y[l1] = Rasterizer.viewport_center_y + (z << 9) / y;
    }

    Rasterizer.fill_alpha = 0;
    count = oblique.face_vertex_a.length;
    for (int j2 = 0; j2 < count; j2++) {
      int a = oblique.face_vertex_a[j2];
      int b = oblique.face_vertex_b[j2];
      int c = oblique.face_vertex_c[j2];
      int a_x = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_x[a];
      int b_x = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_x[b];
      int c_x = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_x[c];
      int a_y = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_y[a];
      int b_y = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_y[b];
      int c_y = ObliqueTile.vertex_view_y[c];
      if ((a_x - b_x) * (c_y - b_y) - (a_y - b_y) * (c_x - b_x) > 0) {
        Rasterizer.clipped_scan = false;
        if (a_x < 0 || b_x < 0 || c_x < 0 || a_x > Raster.clip_view_right || b_x > Raster.clip_view_right || c_x > Raster.clip_view_right)
          Rasterizer.clipped_scan = true;
        if (picking_tiles && point_in_triangle(click_x, click_y, a_x, a_y, b_x, b_y, c_x, c_y)) {
          picked_tile_x = tile_x;
          picked_tile_y = tile_y;
        }
        if (oblique.face_texture == null || oblique.face_texture[j2] == -1) {
          if (oblique.face_color_a[j2] != 0xbc614e)
            Rasterizer.gouraud_triangle(a_y, b_y, c_y, a_x, b_x, c_x, oblique.face_color_a[j2], oblique.face_color_b[j2], oblique.face_color_c[j2]);
        } else if (!tile_texturing_disabled) {
          if (oblique.level)
            Rasterizer.textured_triangle(a_y, b_y, c_y, a_x, b_x, c_x, oblique.face_color_a[j2], oblique.face_color_b[j2], oblique.face_color_c[j2], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[0], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[1], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[3], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[0], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[1], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[3], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[0], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[1], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[3], oblique.face_texture[j2]);
          else
            Rasterizer.textured_triangle(a_y, b_y, c_y, a_x, b_x, c_x, oblique.face_color_a[j2], oblique.face_color_b[j2], oblique.face_color_c[j2], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[a], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[b], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_x[c], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[a], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[b], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_z[c], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[a], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[b], ObliqueTile.vertex_camera_y[c], oblique.face_texture[j2]);
        } else {
          int color = tile_texture_replacements[oblique.face_texture[j2]];
          Rasterizer.gouraud_triangle(a_y, b_y, c_y, a_x, b_x, c_x, shade(color, oblique.face_color_a[j2]), shade(color, oblique.face_color_b[j2]), shade(color, oblique.face_color_c[j2]));
        }
      }
    }
  }

Read full topic

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Did that really fix the z-sorting? Strange… well, glad it’s fixed anyways. To help the speed, I’d suggest you not only avoid allocating many short-lived objects (not only the vector objects), but maybe even unroll your square matrix multiplication:

var a00 = matrix[0][0]; var a01 = matrix[0][1]; var a02 = matrix[0][2]; var a03 = matrix[0][3]; var a10 = matrix[1][0]; var a11 = matrix[1][1]; var a12 = matrix[1][2]; var a13 = matrix[1][3]; var a20 = matrix[2][0]; var a21 = matrix[2][1]; var a22 = matrix[2][2]; var a23 = matrix[2][3]; var a30 = matrix[3][0]; var a31 = matrix[3][1]; var a32 = matrix[3][2]; var a33 = matrix[3][3]; var b00 = b[0][0]; var b01 = b[0][1]; var b02 = b[0][2]; var b03 = b[0][3]; var b10 = b[1][0]; var b11 = b[1][1]; var b12 = b[1][2]; var b13 = b[1][3]; var b20 = b[2][0]; var b21 = b[2][1]; var b22 = b[2][2]; var b23 = b[2][3]; var b30 = b[3][0]; var b31 = b[3][1]; var b32 = b[3][2]; var b33 = b[3][3]; matrix[0][0] = a00 * b00 + a01 * b10 + a02 * b20 + a03 * b30; matrix[0][1] = a00 * b01 + a01 * b11 + a02 * b21 + a03 * b31; matrix[0][2] = a00 * b02 + a01 * b12 + a02 * b22 + a03 * b32; matrix[0][3] = a00 * b03 + a01 * b13 + a02 * b23 + a03 * b33; matrix[1][0] = a10 * b00 + a11 * b10 + a12 * b20 + a13 * b30; matrix[1][1] = a10 * b01 + a11 * b11 + a12 * b21 + a13 * b31; matrix[1][2] = a10 * b02 + a11 * b12 + a12 * b22 + a13 * b32; matrix[1][3] = a10 * b03 + a11 * b13 + a12 * b23 + a13 * b33; matrix[2][0] = a20 * b00 + a21 * b10 + a22 * b20 + a23 * b30; matrix[2][1] = a20 * b01 + a21 * b11 + a22 * b21 + a23 * b31; matrix[2][2] = a20 * b02 + a21 * b12 + a22 * b22 + a23 * b32; matrix[2][3] = a20 * b03 + a21 * b13 + a22 * b23 + a23 * b33; matrix[3][0] = a30 * b00 + a31 * b10 + a32 * b20 + a33 * b30; matrix[3][1] = a30 * b01 + a31 * b11 + a32 * b21 + a33 * b31; matrix[3][2] = a30 * b02 + a31 * b12 + a32 * b22 + a33 * b32; matrix[3][3] = a30 * b03 + a31 * b13 + a32 * b23 + a33 * b33;
In fact, you might even consider deconstructing the matrix arrays into a bunch of element variables like the a00, etc. above, which might provide good cache-friendly locality. It should also be known that matrix multiplication can be even further simplified with a priori information about what the particular matrix represents (i.e. an affine transformation using homogeneous coordinates).

Read full topic

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

Solved the zsorting issue.

        faces.sort(function(f0,f1){
            //sort method by veer Note: possible issues due to lack of full perspective implementation. 
           
            var v0 = f0.getNormal();
            var v1 = f1.getNormal();
          
            return v0.z - v1.z;      
            
     
        });

also some serious performance fail: http://silabsoft.org/pos3d/teapot.html

item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

it shouldn’t be a worry at the moment, but if this becomes highly performance dependent you may want to regard the advice here (particularly “avoid vector objects if at all possible”)

edit: also i’m no javascript aficionado but why is every function in that vector ‘class’ duplicated for both the prototype and the object itself? can’t you just set the object members to the prototypes so you only have to define each function once?

item.source: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

you have to put this. or it goes undefined.

and ‘this.’ aside this is what i have come up with:

POS3D.Vector = (function() {
    function Vector(x,y,z) {
        this.x = x; //instance variable
        this.y = y;
        this.z = z;

    }
    //public shared method
    Vector.prototype.toString = function(){
        return "Vertex: ["+this.x+","+this.y+ ","+this.z+"]"; 
    }
    
    //static method
    Vector.prototype.add = function(v){
        this.x += v.x;
        this.y += v.y;
        this.z += v.z;
    }
    Vector.prototype.subtract = function(v){
        this.x -= v.x;
        this.y -= v.y;
        this.z -= v.z;
    }
    Vector.prototype.divide = function(v){
        this.x /= v.x;
        this.y /= v.y;
        this.z /= v.z;
    }   
    Vector.prototype.multiply = function(v){
        this.x *= v.x;
        this.y *= v.y;
        this.z *= v.z;
    }      
    Vector.prototype.getMagnitude = function(){
        return Math.sqrt(this.x * this.x + this.y * this.y + this.z * this.z);
    }
    Vector.prototype.crossProduct = function(v){
        return new POS3D.Vertex(this.y * v.z - this.z * v.y, this.z * v.x - this.x * v.z, this.x * v.y - this.y * v.x);

    }
    Vector.prototype.dotProduct = function(v){
        return this.x * v.x + this.y * v.y + this.z * v.z;
    }
    Vector.prototype.normalize = function(){
               
        var mag = this.getMagnitude();
        this.x /= mag;
        this.y /= mag; 
        this.z /= mag;
    }
    Vector.add = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vector(v0.x+v1.x,v0.y+v1.y,v0.z+v1.z);
    }
    Vector.subtract = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vector(v0.x-v1.x,v0.y-v1.y,v0.z-v1.z);
    };  
    Vector.divide = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vector(v0.x/v1.x,v0.y/v1.y,v0.z/v1.z);
    };  
    Vector.multiply = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vector(v0.x*v1.x,v0.y*v1.y,v0.z*v1.z);
    }; 
    Vector.getMagnitude = function(v){
        return Math.sqrt(v.x * v.x + v.y * v.y + v.z * v.z);
    }
    Vector.crossProduct = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vector(v0.y * v1.z - v0.z * v1.y, v0.z * v1.x - v0.x * v1.z, v0.x * v1.y - v0.y * v1.x);
    }
    Vector.dotProduct = function(v0,v1){
        return v0.x * v1.x + v0.y * v1.y + v0.z * v1.z;
    }
    Vector.normalize = function(v){
               
        var mag = v.getMagnitude();
        return new POS3D.Vector(v.x / mag, v.y / mag, v.z / mag);
    }
    return Vector;
})();

Read full topic
item.source: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Yes, I believe something like that, though I’d implore you to rename it “Vector” since it more wholly captures the essence of the object – well, just thinking about it, vertex arithmetic doesn’t make much sense
One annoyance is the constant explicit this. when referencing the local object’s properties, but essentially that’s it.

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

after much further reading i think it should be more like this:

POS3D.Vertex = (function() {
    function Vertex(x,y,z) {
        this.x = x; //instance variable
        this.y = y;
        this.z = z;
    }
    
    //public shared method
    Vertex.prototype.toString = function(){
        return "Vertex: ["+this.x+","+this.y+ ","+this.z+"]"; 
    }
    
    //static method
    Vertex.add = function(v0,v1){
        return new POS3D.Vertex(v0.x+v1.x,v0.y+v1.y,v0.z+v1.z);
    };
    return Vertex;
})();

Read full topic
item.source: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

so for example my commenting on the vertex “class”

POS3D.Vertex = (function(){
    function Vertex(x0,y0,z0) {
        var x = x0;
        var y = y0;
        var z = z0;
        
        //public instance method
        this.add = function(v) {
            return new POS3D.Vertex(x + v.x, y + v.y, z + v.z);
        }
        
        this.subtract = function(v) {
            return new POS3D.Vertex(x - v.x, y - v.y, z - v.z);
        }
        
        this.multiply  =function(i) {
            return new POS3D.Vertex(x * i, y * i, z * i);
        }
        
        this.divide = function(i) {
            return new POS3D.Vertex(x / i, y / i, z / i);
        }
        return{
            //public method
            toString : function(){
                return "Vertex: ["+x+","+y+ ","+z+"]";
            },
            getX : function(){
                return x
            },
            getY : function(){
                return y
            },
            getZ : function(){
                return z
            },
            getMagnitude : function(){
                return Math.sqrt(x * x + y * y + z * z);
            },
            getCrossProduct : function(v) {
                return new POS3D.Vertex(y * v.z - z * v.y, z * v.x - x * v.z, x * v.y - y * v.x);
            },
            getDotProduct : function(v) {
                return x * v.x + y * v.y + z * v.z;
            },
            normalize : function(){
                var mag = this.getMagnitude();
                return new POS3D.Vertex(x / mag, y / mag, z / mag);
            }
        }
    }
    return Vertex;
})();

would be correct?

Read full topic
item.source: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)

item.title: Pile of Silab 3D - Javascript 3d Rendering (now with cool dragons and shit)
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:12, topic:448771”]l2zsortingsilab

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

asgfhdfg[/quote]
Your z-sort routine is nearly identical to the one I posted which silabsoft now uses…

[code] public Vertex getCenter() { Vertex t = Math3D.add(vv, vv1); Vertex t2 = Math3D.add(t, vv2); return Math3D.div(t2, 3); }

public int compareTo(Face a) {
return (int)(getCenter().getZ() - a.getCenter().getZ());
}[/code]


… is comparing the two faces’ centroid Z in ascending order, exactly what the following does:

this.compare = function(f0, f1) { var v0 = f0.getVerticies(); var v1 = f1.getVerticies(); var sum_z0 = 0; for (var x = 0; x < v0.length; ++x) sum_z0 += v0[x].getZ(); var sum_z1 = 0; for (var x = 0; x < v1.length; ++x) sum_z1 += v1[x].getZ(); return sum_z0 - sum_z1; }

[quote=“mopman_sucks, post:11, topic:448771”][quote author=veer link=topic=551658.msg4042097#msg4042097 date=1341731431]
Well, the way I posted allows for distinct camera/viewer, which is how RuneScape does it. Most of my 3d knowledge comes from that, so heh
[/quote]
veer on your suggestion you posted on github I attempted to implement something similar but I seem to have broken everything in the process. I know the biggest problem is I am trying to force a “class” like structure in javascript which is the ultimate taboo. Do you have any suggestions that I can get a somewhat happy medium?[/quote]
Yeah… I accidentally posted broken code. Essentially, this is the typical pattern I see in javascript which I failed at demonstrating:

[code]var MyObj = (function() { // namespace
var privateSharedVar = ‘foo’;

function privateSharedFunction() {
    // has access to privateSharedVar
    // may also access publicSharedVar via explicit MyObj.prototype
    // can't be called via this
}

function MyObj() { // constructor
    var privateInstanceVar = 'bar';
    this.publicInstanceVar = 'baz';

    function privateInstanceFunction() {
        // has access to all vars
        // can't be called via this
    };

    this.publicInstanceMethod = function() {
        // has access to all vars
        // also known as a priviledged method
    };
}

MyObj.prototype.publicSharedVar = 'quux';

MyObj.prototype.publicSharedMethod = function() {
    // has access to shared and public vars
    // canonical way for method creation:
    // try to use this as much as possible
};

return MyObj;

})();[/code]
(as seen here)

Read full topic
